<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 276, 905, 291]]<|/det|>
9702/42  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 376, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 A Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2021  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 326, 905, 340]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 361, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 559]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 602]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 100.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 73, 124, 88]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 102, 625, 560]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) \((\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{- 1})\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1u = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81\mathrm{m s}^{- 2}\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 101, 615, 121]]<|/det|>
\[c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{-1}\]

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 168, 88]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 106, 555, 144]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 163, 520, 180]]<|/det|>
\[W = \rho \Delta V\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 194, 532, 223]]<|/det|>
\[\phi = -\frac{Gm}{r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 235, 520, 252]]<|/det|>
\[\rho = \rho gh\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 262, 556, 295]]<|/det|>
\[\rho = \frac{1}{3}\frac{Nm}{V}\langle c^2\rangle\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 304, 536, 321]]<|/det|>
\[a = -\omega^2 x\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 339, 601, 375]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \nu_0\cos \omega t\] \[\nu = \pm \omega \sqrt{(\chi_0^2 - x^2)}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 380, 536, 415]]<|/det|>
\[f_0 = \frac{f_s\nu}{v\pm\nu_s}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 425, 536, 459]]<|/det|>
\[V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_0r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 467, 623, 486]]<|/det|>
\[1 / C = 1 / C_1 + 1 / C_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 500, 593, 520]]<|/det|>
\[C = C_1 + C_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 530, 522, 555]]<|/det|>
\[W = \frac{1}{2} QV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 570, 525, 588]]<|/det|>
\[I = A n v q\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 603, 593, 622]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_1 + R_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 637, 623, 655]]<|/det|>
\[1 / R = 1 / R_1 + 1 / R_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 668, 512, 702]]<|/det|>
\[V_{\mathrm{H}} = \frac{BI}{ntq}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 715, 556, 733]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_0\sin \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 747, 576, 766]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_0\exp (-\lambda t)\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[444, 777, 532, 811]]<|/det|>
\[\lambda = \frac{0.693}{t_{\frac{1}{2}}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[295, 72, 700, 88]]<|/det|>
Answer **all** the questions in the spaces provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 118, 96, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 119, 146, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 118, 547, 136]]<|/det|>
State what is meant by _centripetal acceleration_.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 240, 146, 259]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 240, 920, 274]]<|/det|>
An unpowered toy car moves freely along a smooth track that is initially horizontal. The track contains a vertical circular loop around which the car travels, as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 285, 836, 497]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 513, 532, 532]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 545, 920, 578]]<|/det|>
The mass of the car is \(230\mathrm{g}\) and the diameter of the loop is \(62\mathrm{cm}\). Assume that the resistive forces acting on the car are negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 591, 181, 609]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 591, 920, 624]]<|/det|>
State what happens to the magnitude of the centripetal acceleration of the car as it moves around the loop from X to Y.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[200, 636, 920, 655]]<|/det|>
<form>.................................................................................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 668, 181, 686]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 668, 920, 700]]<|/det|>
Explain, if the car remains in contact with the track, why the centripetal acceleration of the car at point Y must be greater than \(9.8 \text{m s}^{-2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 775, 920, 794]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 764, 89]]<|/det|>
The initial speed at which the car in **(b)** moves along the track is \(3.8 \text{m s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 848, 120]]<|/det|>
Determine whether the car is in contact with the track at point Y. Show your working.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 338, 920, 356]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 369, 148, 387]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 194, 920, 227]]<|/det|>
A moon of mass \(M\) and radius \(R\) orbits a planet of mass \(3M\) and radius \(2R\). At a particular time, the distance between their centres is \(D\), as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 511, 920, 545]]<|/det|>
The variation with \(x\) of the gravitational potential \(\phi\) at point P, for points between the planet and the moon, is shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 177, 920, 196]]<|/det|>
<form>................................................................................................................

State two other assumptions of the kinetic theory of gases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 241, 217, 259]]<|/det|>
<label>1.</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 260, 920, 279]]<|/det|>

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 380, 920, 414]]<|/det|>
A molecule of an ideal gas has mass \(m\) and is contained in a cubic box of side length \(L\). The molecule is moving with velocity \(u\) towards the face of the box that is shaded in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 425, 725, 588]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 603, 524, 621]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 635, 910, 653]]<|/det|>
The molecule collides elastically with the shaded face and the face opposite to it alternately.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 666, 554, 683]]<|/det|>
Deduce expressions, in terms of \(m\), \(u\) and \(L\), for:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 696, 181, 715]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 696, 873, 715]]<|/det|>
the magnitude of the change in momentum of the molecule on colliding with a face

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[384, 794, 920, 812]]<|/det|>
<form>change in momentum = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 825, 181, 844]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 825, 828, 844]]<|/det|>
the time between consecutive collisions of the molecule with the shaded face

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[527, 885, 920, 904]]<|/det|>
<form>time = ............................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 72, 180, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 707, 89]]<|/det|>
the average force exerted by the molecule on the shaded face

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[520, 133, 920, 151]]<|/det|>
<form>force = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[896, 134, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 165, 181, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 164, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
the pressure on the shaded face if the force in **(iii)** is exerted over the whole area of the face.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[489, 225, 920, 243]]<|/det|>
<form>pressure = ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[916, 227, 928, 245]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 256, 144, 275]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 256, 922, 291]]<|/det|>
When the model described in **(b)** is extended to three dimensions, and to a gas containing \(N\) molecules, each of mass \(m\), travelling with mean-square speed \(\langle c^2 \rangle\), it can be shown that

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 304, 559, 327]]<|/det|>
\[pV = \frac{1}{3} Nm\langle c^2\rangle\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 338, 769, 356]]<|/det|>
where \(p\) is the pressure exerted by the gas and \(V\) is the volume of the gas.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 369, 920, 403]]<|/det|>
Use this expression, together with the equation of state of an ideal gas, to show that the average translational kinetic energy \(E_{\mathrm{K}}\) of a molecule of an ideal gas is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 415, 541, 440]]<|/det|>
\[E_{\mathrm{K}} = \frac{3}{2} kT\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 450, 873, 468]]<|/det|>
where \(T\) is the thermodynamic temperature of the gas and \(k\) is the Boltzmann constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 641, 920, 660]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 672, 148, 691]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 672, 591, 691]]<|/det|>
The mass of a hydrogen molecule is \(3.34 \times 10^{-27} \text{kg}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 702, 920, 736]]<|/det|>
Use the expression for \(E_{\mathrm{K}}\) in **(c)** to determine the root-mean-square (r.m.s.) speed of a molecule of hydrogen gas at \(25^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[462, 892, 920, 910]]<|/det|>
<form>r.m.s. speed = ............................................... $\text{ms}^{-1}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[831, 922, 920, 939]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 843, 90]]<|/det|>
A trolley on a smooth surface is attached by springs to fixed blocks as shown in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 102, 843, 288]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 307, 532, 325]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 338, 920, 388]]<|/det|>
The trolley oscillates horizontally about its equilibrium position with an amplitude of \(12\mathrm{cm}\). Fig. 4.2 shows the variation of the acceleration \(a\) of the trolley with displacement \(x\) from its equilibrium position. Friction between the trolley and the surface can be assumed to be negligible.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 399, 799, 687]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 707, 534, 725]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 738, 146, 757]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 737, 920, 771]]<|/det|>
Describe the features of the line in Fig. 4.2 that demonstrate that the motion of the trolley is simple harmonic.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 848, 920, 866]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 728, 89]]<|/det|>
Use Fig. 4.2 to determine the period \(T\) of the oscillations of the trolley.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 240, 920, 259]]<|/det|>
<form>T = .................................................... s

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 273, 144, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 273, 178, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 272, 920, 306]]<|/det|>
On the line of the graph of Fig. 4.2, label with the letter P one point where the kinetic energy of the trolley is zero.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 286, 920, 305]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 318, 181, 336]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 318, 920, 368]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 381, 920, 400]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 185, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 920, 103]]<|/det|> When audio signals are transmitted over long distances, modulation of radio waves is used. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 117, 546, 135]]<|/det|> Suggest a reason why modulation is used. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 152, 920, 170]]<|/det|>
........................................................................................................................ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 178, 920, 196]]<|/det|> ........................................................................................................................ <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 210, 181, 228]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 210, 920, 243]]<|/det|> State a technical advantage and a technical disadvantage of using frequency modulation rather than amplitude modulation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 256, 918, 274]]<|/det|> advantage: .................................................................................................................... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 307, 918, 324]]<|/det|> disadvantage: .................................................................................................................... <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 365, 920, 384]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 396, 148, 415]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 396, 920, 428]]<|/det|> An audio signal of amplitude \(2.0 \mu \text{V}\) and frequency \(4.2 \text{kHz}\) is to be transmitted using a carrier wave of amplitude \(10.0 \text{mV}\) and frequency \(100 \text{kHz}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 443, 710, 460]]<|/det|> Either amplitude modulation or frequency modulation may be used. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 475, 579, 492]]<|/det|> The amplitude modulation is at a rate of \(1 \text{mV} \mu \text{V}^{-1}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 489, 583, 507]]<|/det|> The frequency modulation is at a rate of \(5 \text{kHz} \mu \text{V}^{-1}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 520, 920, 553]]<|/det|> Complete Table 5.1 to show the maximum and minimum values of the amplitude and of the frequency of the modulated wave for each type of modulation. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 567, 541, 584]]<|/det|> Table 5.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 593, 920, 742]]<|/det|>
amplitude/mVfrequency/kHz
minimummaximumminimummaximum
amplitude modulation
frequency modulation
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 742, 920, 761]]<|/det|> [4] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 774, 146, 792]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 774, 710, 792]]<|/det|> For the amplitude modulated wave in (b), determine the bandwidth. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[479, 834, 920, 852]]<|/det|> bandwidth = .................................................... kHz <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 865, 920, 883]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 866, 920, 884]]<|/det|> [Total: 8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 358, 89]]<|/det|>
Define electric potential.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 196, 141, 214]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 920, 244]]<|/det|>
An isolated conducting sphere in a vacuum has radius \(r\) and is initially uncharged. It is then charged by friction so that it carries a final charge \(Q\). This charge can be considered to be acting at the centre of the sphere.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 257, 920, 291]]<|/det|>
By considering the electric potential at its surface, show that the capacitance \(C\) of the sphere is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 304, 544, 322]]<|/det|>
\[C = 4\pi \epsilon_0 r\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 335, 492, 353]]<|/det|>
where \(\epsilon_0\) is the permittivity of free space.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 494, 920, 512]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 523, 146, 541]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 523, 920, 555]]<|/det|>
The dome of an electrostatic generator is a spherical conductor of radius \(13 \text{cm}\). It is initially charged so that the electric potential at the surface is \(4.5 \text{kV}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 570, 920, 616]]<|/det|>
A smaller isolated sphere of radius \(5.2 \text{cm}\), initially uncharged, is brought near to the dome. Sparking causes a current between the two spheres until they reach the same potential. Assume that any charge on a sphere may be considered to act as a point charge at its centre.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 631, 695, 648]]<|/det|>
Calculate the charge that is transferred between the two spheres.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[507, 882, 920, 900]]<|/det|>
<form>charge = .................................................... C [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 913, 920, 930]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>

<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 438, 920, 471]]<|/det|>
State, with a reason, how the magnitude of the force acting on wire P compares with the magnitude of the force acting on wire Q.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 606, 920, 640]]<|/det|>
State how the direction of the force on wire P compares with the direction of the force on wire Q.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 685, 920, 702]]<|/det|>
